We have fixed the hadoop dependency issue for HDFS fetcher along with JF's commit that you mentioned above and  https://github.com/linkedin/pinot/pull/1973. (If Hadoop jar does not exist, do not initialize HDFS fetcher)

I recommend not to include Hadoop dependency for Pinot because Hadoop introduced a lot of library version conflicts and we spent 2-3 days to resolve conflict issues for our internal release.

I would suggest to keep it as `provided`.

Looks good. Does caching still work for third-party connectors, e.g. autometrics?

Kishore, thanks for your comment. Fair point regarding the benchmarks, and the slides are very helpful.

Is it fair in assuming that druid and pinot covers the same use cases. Apart from support for star tree index, are there any differences in philosophy or tradeoffs made in pinot compared to druid? 
I think what I am asking is apart from perf difference for my use cases, are there anything else you think would be worth considering in the evaluation?

Architecture is very similar - lambda. Pinot has a new component called
minion which will remove the need to have an offline component but this is
not ready for production. There is no SPOF in Pinot. Use of Helix for
cluster management is a big plus point for Pinot. It enables self
serve scenarios such as create table, rebalance tables, tag nodes, create
custom topology etc. Almost all the operations can be done dynamically
without needing to restart the servers. I haven't operated a Druid cluster,
so I can't really comment on the cluster management aspects of Druid, apart
from the fact that it needs an additional MySQL.

*Data format*

   - Druid mandates inverted index for all columns whereas it's optional in
   pinot and can be generated on demand when the query pattern changes. This
   can impact the segment size drastically.
   - Different encodings supported in Pinot - dictionary encoded, RLE for
   sorted columns, no dictionary snappy compression. These can be configured
   for each column.
   - Star tree index is definitely a big differentiator - this basically
   means you get Druid + Kylin in one system and you can choose the mode based
   on your qps and latency requirements.

*Query execution model is very different*

Pinot has a planning phase and execution phase and has the concept of
operator tree similar to how most DBs work. This means Pinot can do
optimizations on a per query basis and base it on the metadata of the
segment. For e.g if there are filters on two columns - one of them has
inverted index and the other does not. Irrespective of how the predicates
appear in the query - Pinot will reorder the predicate evaluation
appropriately. This is just an example, there are many other scenarios. In
practice, we have seen blindly having inverted index on columns performs
worse than having an inverted index on key columns and use scan based
filter for remaining columns.

In contrast, Druid has a constant plan - use an inverted index to get the
matching docs, scan the filtered docs and perform group by/aggregation.

*Features*

   - Most of the commonly used features are available in both Pinot and
   Druid. I think Druid does have support for Theta Sketches and Hyperloglog
   for distinct. Pinot as of now only supports HyperLogLog.
   - Group by along with top k result accuracy - by default we found Pinot
   group by results are more accurate than Druid. In both systems, there is
   some trimming done at node level (returning all results from each node will
   be inefficient). But in  Druid, we found that it trims the result at
   segment level as well. This might show up as Druid being a bit better for
   some queries in terms of latency but the results can be highly inaccurate.

*Documentation*

   - Druid definitely has better documentation than Pinot :-).

Hope this helps.
Note: I haven't really looked deep into Druid code base nor have I operated
a Druid cluster, so some of the info I have provided might be outdated. If
there are any Druid users reading this, please feel free to add your
comments.

thanks,
Kishore G

Can you describe what that execution plan looks like? Is it achieved with an additional "partial shuffle" or by forcing nodes to take on all of the segments in their hash-space?

We support both modes but we don't capitalize on partitioned data as of now
for distinct operators. Let me explain -  We can ensure that segment with
same hash always gets assigned to the same node replica. The execution plan
is the same for both cases although I see your point that the query could
have been completely evaluated within the server node and broker could have
summed up the numbers from each server. This should be straightforward to
add such an aggregation operator to compute distinct from partitioned data.

Pinot doesn't support explicit hints. We set the partitioning scheme in the
table config e.g Data is partitioned on userId. During execution, if Pinot
sees a predicate on column userId such as userId=X, it automatically
filters out all other segments that don't belong to this partition. We
store the partition hash as part of each segment metadata. The broker
computes the subset of segments to process and routes the query to nodes
hosting these segments. These segments can be spread across the entire
cluster or few nodes (X) depending on the segment assignment strategy.Note
that X can 1, in which case entire gets executed on 1 node.

We don't do per day shuffle yet. Feel free to start another thread to go
over this in detail.
